From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 27 January 2018 at 09:40, milind.dalvi14@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> This is not related to NEAT, however, I thought this might be a good place to ask since there
> are a lot of EC minds in this group.
>
> I am working on creating decision trees using genetic algorithms. Anyone know any
> references to genotype representations for decision trees? I am looking forward to "direct
> encoding" but any views on "indirect encoding" are also appreciated.


I think it depends on the problem you're trying to solve. Random
Forests (RF) is a method based on ensembles of decision trees, which
works very well at modelling low dimensional data or 'spreadsheet
style' data sets - a number of kaggle competitions have been based on
this type of data and RF used to be the go-to approach for winning
those competitions (not sure if that's still the case though, I would
guess not).

My point being that each decision tree (DT) in an RF is very cheap to
construct, and as such I'm not sure what benefit an evolved DT would
give. In fact one of the cool features of RF is that each DT is highly
randomized, i.e. each tree node splits the data into two based on a
(partially) randomly chosen feature (dimension), and either the
optimal split on that dimension (using linear least squares), or the
optimal point with some random noise added, or even just a totally
random split (see Extreme Random Forests). And because we are just
adding new cheap semi-random models to an ensemble rather than
training just one model, the result is that RFs exhibit little to no
overfitting to a given data set, which is fairly unique. I've even
seen RFs *under*fit, i.e. test set data score is /better/ than the
training set data score.

This underfitting is not a feature of RFs per se, but rather it's a
known feature of ensembles, and RFs happen to take the ensemble
approach to an extreme because each DT in the 'forest' is cheap to
compute, and therefore you can build hundreds or thousands of them in
very little time.

If instead you were to apply evolutionary training (or direct gradient
descent) to a single DT then you would once again have a problem of
overfitting to the training data.

Not sure if this answers your question but hopefully/maybe some of
that was useful at some level.

Colin
